prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe 4C12.50 in CO(3-2) with ALMA using a bandwidth of 1823km/s. We use spectral averaging to get a channel resolution of 7.6km/s. The source will fit in a single ALMA 12m primary beam. We use a 1" beam, which will likely just resolve this galaxy. We added CS(7-6) and HCO+(4-3) primarily as detection experiments.
The needed sensitivity on the galaxy is based on a CO(1-0) measurement, and thermal equilibrium was assumed, such that the flux of CO(3-2) was simply 9 times the flux of CO(1-0). Using the 19 Jy-km/s measurement from the 30m and the velocity width of 400 km/s, we estimated the necessary sensitivity per 10km/s channel to be 142mJy, which ALMA is able to reach in its minimum (2min) track length. This will also be able to detect continuum with S/N of 496. We expect that standard calibration techniques will suffice.

We propose to observe 3C218 in CO(3-2) with ALMA using a bandwidth of 1823km/s. We use spectral averaging to get a channel resolution of 7.6km/s. Due to the fact that there is a molecular bridge between 3C218 and its companion, we will observe the system with two pointings with the 12m dishes. We use a 1" beam, which will likely just resolve this galaxy. We added 13CO(3-2) as a detection experiment.
The needed sensitivity on the galaxy is based on a CO(1-0) measurement, and thermal equilibrium was assumed, such that the flux of CO(3-2) was simply 9 times the flux of CO(1-0). Using the 3.8 Jy-km/s measurement from the 30m and the velocity width of 1300 km/s, we estimated the necessary sensitivity per 10km/s channel to be 8.7mJy, which ALMA is able to reach in its minimum (2min) track length. This will also be able to detect continuum with S/N of 189. We expect that standard calibration techniques will suffice.

We propose to observe 3C433 in CO(3-2) with ALMA using a bandwidth of 1823km/s. We use spectral averaging to get a channel resolution of 7.5km/s. We use a 1" beam, which will likely just resolve this galaxy. We added 13CO(3-2) as a detection experiment.
The needed sensitivity on the galaxy is based on a CO(1-0) measurement, and thermal equilibrium was assumed, such that the flux of CO(3-2) was simply 9 times the flux of CO(1-0). Using an estimate from the warm H2 of 3.2e10Msuns and assuming a cold gas fraction of only 10% corresponds to 1.43 Jy-km/s in CO(1-0) (below the upper limit of 4.12 Jy-km/s). Assuming a velocity width of 1000 km/s, we estimated the necessary sensitivity per 10km/s channel to be 4.3mJy, which ALMA is able to reach in its minimum (2min) track length. This will also be able to detect continuum with S/N of 15 for the estimated continuum. We expect that standard calibration techniques will suffice.

We propose to observe HCG57A in CO(3-2) with ALMA using a bandwidth of 1673km/s. We use spectral averaging to get a channel resolution of 7.0km/s. Due to the large angle subtended by HCG57a, we will also include the ACA 7m antennas (with 30" beam) to gain complete information on the system. We use a 2.2" beam, which will likely just resolve this galaxy. We added HCO+(4-3) as a detection experiment.
The needed sensitivity on the galaxy is based on a CO(1-0) measurement, and thermal equilibrium was assumed, such that the flux of CO(3-2) was simply 9 times the flux of CO(1-0). Using the 18.4 Jy-km/s measurement from the 30m and the velocity width of 500 km/s, we estimated the necessary sensitivity per 10km/s channel to be 111mJy, which ALMA is able to reach in its minimum (2min) track length. This will also be able to detect continuum with S/N of 85. We expect that standard calibration techniques will suffice.

We propose to observe HCG79A in CO(3-2) with ALMA using a bandwidth of 1673km/s. We use spectral averaging to get a channel resolution of 6.9km/s. We use a 2.1" beam, which will likely just resolve this galaxy. We added HCO+(4-3) as a detection experiment.
The needed sensitivity on the galaxy is based on a CO(1-0) measurement, and thermal equilibrium was assumed, such that the flux of CO(3-2) was simply 9 times the flux of CO(1-0). Using the 15 Jy-km/s measurement from the CARMA and the velocity width of 400 km/s, we estimated the necessary sensitivity per 10km/s channel to be 150mJy, which ALMA is able to reach in its minimum (2min) track length. This will also be able to detect continuum with S/N of 40. We expect that standard calibration techniques will suffice.

We propose to observe HCG91A in CO(3-2) with ALMA using a bandwidth of 1664km/s. We use spectral averaging to get a channel resolution of 6.9km/s. Due to the large angle subtended by HCG57a, we will also include the ACA 7m antennas (with 30" beam) to gain complete information on the system. We use a 2.2" beam, which will likely just resolve this galaxy. We added HCO+(4-3) as a detection experiment.
The needed sensitivity on the galaxy is based on a CO(1-0) measurement, and thermal equilibrium was assumed, such that the flux of CO(3-2) was simply 9 times the flux of CO(1-0). Using the 74.8 Jy-km/s measurement from the 30m and the velocity width of 517 km/s, we estimated the necessary sensitivity per 10km/s channel to be 433mJy, which ALMA is able to reach in its minimum (2min) track length, though the ACA adds time to the estimate. This will also be able to detect continuum with S/N of 300. We expect that standard calibration techniques will suffice.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A new class of galaxies with very strong molecular hydrogen relative to their polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) emission was discovered by Spitzer in a variety of massive, active galaxies. IR and X-ray observations of these systems indicate the emission is shock-excited by the radio jet (e.g., in radio galaxies) or by galaxy collisions (e.g., in Hickson Compact Groups). Here we propose to use ALMA to map three representative systems of each of these types of shock-excited galaxies in CO to obtain spatial, velocity, and excitation information and thereby infer the impact on star formation in these galaxies

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
